title: Intracerebral Hemorrhage
scope: ** Spontaneous (non-traumatic) intracerebral hemorrhage in adults. Covers acute BP management, anticoagulant reversal, ICH score and prognosis, ICP management, surgical indications, etiology workup, and secondary prevention. Excludes traumatic ICH, subarachnoid hemorrhage (separate template), hemorrhagic transformation of ischemic stroke, and subdural/epidural hematomas.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; thrombocytopenia as cause or complication; transfusion needs
Warfarin-related ICH requires emergent reversal; coagulopathy assessment
Electrolytes; renal function for contrast/medication; hepatic function for coagulopathy
Hyperglycemia worsens ICH outcomes; hypoglycemia mimics stroke
Potential need for blood products, surgery, reversal agents

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Dabigatran (direct thrombin inhibitor) detection; if patient on DOACs

Essential/First-line.timing: Door-to-CT <25 minutes; determines ICH diagnosis, location, volume, IVH, hydrocephalus, midline shift
Essential/First-line.target: Hemorrhage location (deep: basal ganglia/thalamus = hypertensive; lobar: CAA, tumor, AVM), volume (ABC/2 method), intraventricular hemorrhage (IVH), hydrocephalus, midline shift >5mm

Essential/First-line.timing: With initial CT; identify "spot sign" (active contrast extravasation = hematoma expansion risk), underlying vascular malformation (AVM, aneurysm)
Essential/First-line.target: Spot sign (30-50% risk of expansion); AVM; aneurysm; dural AV fistula; Moyamoya
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Contrast allergy; renal impairment (benefit outweighs risk in emergency)

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; neurogenic cardiac injury; arrhythmia; QTc prolongation risk
Essential/First-line.target: Normal; ST changes may be neurogenic

Essential/First-line.timing: At 6h and 24h OR any neurologic decline; assess for hematoma expansion (>33% or >6mL increase from baseline = significant expansion)
Essential/First-line.target: Stable hematoma size; no new hemorrhage; no hydrocephalus progression

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553) (include GRE/SWI sequences)
Extended.timing: Within 24-72h when stable; or urgently if underlying mass/AVM suspected
Extended.target: Underlying tumor; cavernous malformation; microbleeds (CAA pattern: lobar; hypertensive: deep). SWI shows microhemorrhages

Extended.timing: If cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) suspected as cause of hemorrhagic venous infarct
Young patient (<50) with lobar ICH and no clear etiology; suspected AVM/aneurysm where CTA inconclusive; negative initial CTA but high suspicion
Extended.target: AVM; aneurysm; dural AV fistula; Moyamoya; vasculitis

Extended.timing: Repeat at 3-6 months; small AVM may be compressed by acute hematoma and missed initially
Neurogenic cardiac injury; baseline cardiac function; endocarditis if mycotic aneurysm suspected
If altered consciousness disproportionate to hemorrhage size; suspected seizures
Extended.target: Non-convulsive seizures; NCSE (seen in 20-30% of ICH patients)

Extended.timing: Aspiration; pulmonary edema (neurogenic); baseline for ventilator

Rare/Specialized.timing: If underlying tumor, vasculitis, or amyloid angiopathy suspected and non-invasive workup inconclusive
CAA diagnosis in lobar ICH with microbleeds

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: ALL ICH patients; BP is most important modifiable risk factor

dosing.instructions: Target SBP <130 mmHg (SPS3 trial, PROGRESS trial); agent choice per comorbidities (ACE-I, ARB, CCB, thiazide)

Secondary Prevention (After Acute Phase).indication: Risk-benefit discussion; SPARCL showed small increased ICH risk with atorvastatin but overall cardiovascular benefit. AHA 2022: statin not contraindicated after ICH

dosing.instructions: Per cardiovascular risk; individualize

Patient / Family Instructions.item: ICH is serious but outcomes vary; early aggressive treatment improves survival
Call 911 if: sudden headache, new weakness, speech changes, altered consciousness
Blood pressure control is the MOST IMPORTANT factor in preventing recurrence
Take all medications as prescribed; never stop blood pressure medications without physician guidance
Do NOT restart anticoagulation or antiplatelet without specific neurology/cardiology guidance
Home blood pressure monitoring daily; keep log; target per physician guidance
Follow-up with neurology in 2-4 weeks; neurosurgery if applicable

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Alcohol cessation or limitation (heavy drinking increases ICH risk)
Avoid excessive anticoagulation (keep INR in range if on warfarin)

differential.features: Prior ischemic infarct on imaging; onset timing suggests ischemic → hemorrhagic evolution
differential.tests: CT/MRI timing; DWI changes preceding hemorrhage

differential.diagnosis: Cerebral venous thrombosis (CVT) with hemorrhagic infarct
differential.features: Headache, seizures, often young women (OCPs, pregnancy); hemorrhage doesn't respect arterial territory; parasagittal location
Subacute symptoms preceding hemorrhage; ring enhancement around hemorrhage; disproportionate edema
differential.tests: MRI with contrast (underlying enhancing mass); biopsy

differential.features: Lobar location (NOT deep); age >55; recurrent lobar hemorrhages; cortical superficial siderosis; multiple lobar microbleeds on SWI
differential.tests: MRI SWI (lobar microbleeds, superficial siderosis); Boston criteria

differential.features: Younger patient; recurrent hemorrhages at same location; AVM on CTA/DSA; cavernoma on MRI (popcorn appearance)
Subarachnoid + intraparenchymal hemorrhage; near aneurysm location
Deep location (putamen, thalamus, pons, cerebellum); history of poorly controlled HTN
differential.tests: Clinical; typical location; no underlying lesion on workup

differential.features: Young adults or Asian patients; recurrent stroke; stenotic proximal vessels with collateral network
differential.tests: MRA (ICA/MCA stenosis with Moyamoya collaterals); DSA

differential.features: Multiple hemorrhages; known coagulopathy or anticoagulant use
History of trauma; scalp laceration; subdural or epidural components
